info.title: Assigning a PCI device to a virtual machine

section.title: Environment
section.para: This document applies to the following products and product versions:

section.title: Introduction
section.para: &libvirt; is a unified interface to various virtualization solutions. &libvirt; virtual machines are typically managed by a command line utility called &virsh; or an application with a graphical user interface called &vmm;.

Assigning a &vmhost;'s PCI device to a &vmguest;—also known as &pciback;—dedicates the PCI device's resources to the &vmguest;. After the PCI device is assigned, it cannot be used by the &vmhost; or by any other &vmguest; on the same &vmhost;.
In this article, you will learn how to assign &vmhost;'s PCI device to a &vmguest; using both &virsh; and &vmm;.

listitem.para: A &sle;-based client machine with libvirt-client and virt-manager installed.
At least one connection to a valid &vmhost; configured by &vmm; or &libvirt;.
An existing &libvirt;-based virtual machine on the &vmhost;.

section.title: Assigning a PCI device with &virsh;
section.para: To assign a &vmhost;'s PCI device to a &vmguest; with &virsh;, follow these steps:

step.para: Identify the host PCI device to assign to the &vmguest;. The following example identifies a DEC network card:
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;lspci -nn [...] 03:07.0 Ethernet controller [0200]: Digital Equipment Corporation DECchip \ 21140 [FasterNet] [1011:0009] (rev 22) [...]
step.para: Write down the device ID (03:07.0 in this case).

Gather detailed information about the device using virsh nodedev-dumpxml ID. To get the ID, replace the colon and the period in the device ID (03:07.0) with underscores. Prefix the result with pci_0000_: pci_0000_03_07_0.
step.screen: &prompt.sudo;virsh nodedev-dumpxml pci_0000_03_07_0 <device> <name>pci_0000_03_07_0</name> <path>/sys/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:14.4/0000:03:07.0</path> <parent>pci_0000_00_14_4</parent> <driver> <name>tulip</name> </driver> <capability type='pci'> <domain>0</domain> <bus>3</bus> <slot>7</slot> <function>0</function> <product id='0x0009'>DECchip 21140 [FasterNet]</product> <vendor id='0x1011'>Digital Equipment Corporation</vendor> <numa node='0'/> </capability> </device>
step.para: Write down the values for domain, bus, and function.
Detach the device from the host system:

tip.title: Multi-function PCI devices
tip.para: When using a multi-function PCI device that does not support FLR (function level reset) or PM (power management) reset, you need to detach all its functions from the &vmhost;. The whole device must be reset for security reasons. libvirt will refuse to assign the device if one of its functions is still in use by the &vmhost; or another &vmguest;.

step.para: Convert the domain, bus, slot, and function value from decimal to hexadecimal. In our example, domain = 0, bus = 3, slot = 7, and function = 0. Ensure that the values are inserted in the right order:
Run virsh edit on your domain, and add the following device entry in the <devices> section using the result from the previous step:
step.screen: <hostdev mode='subsystem' type='pci' managed='yes'> <source> <address domain='0x0' bus='0x03' slot='0x07' function='0x0'/> </source> </hostdev>

tip.title: managed compared to unmanaged
tip.para: libvirt recognizes two modes for handling PCI devices: they can be either managed or unmanaged. In the managed case, libvirt handles all details of unbinding the device from the existing driver if needed, resetting the device, binding it to vfio-pci before starting the domain, etc. When the domain is terminated or the device is removed from the domain, libvirt unbinds from vfio-pci and rebinds to the original driver in the case of a managed device. If the device is unmanaged, the user must ensure all of these management aspects of the device are done before assigning it to a domain, and after the device is no longer used by the domain.

step.para: In the example above, the managed='yes' option means that the device is managed. To switch the device mode to unmanaged, set managed='no' in the listing above. If you do so, you need to take care of the related driver with the virsh nodedev-detach and virsh nodedev-reattach commands. Prior to starting the &vmguest; you need to detach the device from the host by running virsh nodedev-detach pci_0000_03_07_0. In case the &vmguest; is not running, you can make the device available for the host by running virsh nodedev-reattach pci_0000_03_07_0.
Shut down the &vmguest; and disable &selnx; if it is running on the host.
Start your &vmguest; to make the assigned PCI device available:

important.title: &slsa;11 SP4 &kvm; guests
important.para: On a newer &qemu; machine type (pc-i440fx-2.0 or higher) with &slsa;11 SP4 &kvm; guests, the acpiphp module is not loaded by default in the guest. This module must be loaded to enable hotplugging of disk and network devices. To load the module manually, use the command modprobe acpiphp. It is also possible to autoload the module by adding install acpiphp /bin/true to the /etc/modprobe.conf.local file.

important.title: &kvm; guests using &qemu; Q35 machine type
important.para: &kvm; guests using the &qemu; Q35 machine type have a PCI topology that includes a pcie-root controller and seven pcie-root-port controllers. The pcie-root controller does not support hotplugging. Each pcie-root-port controller supports hotplugging a single PCIe device. PCI controllers cannot be hotplugged, so plan accordingly and add more pcie-root-ports if more than seven PCIe devices will be hotplugged. A pcie-to-pci-bridge controller can be added to support hotplugging legacy PCI devices. See for more information about PCI topology between &qemu; machine types.

section.title: Assigning PCI device with &vmm;
section.para: To assign a &vmhost;'s PCI device to a &vmguest; with &vmm;, follow these steps:

step.para: Double-click a &vmguest; entry in the &vmm; to open its console and switch to the Details view with View Details .
Click Add Hardware and choose the PCI Host Device category in the left panel. A list of available PCI devices appears in the right part of the window.
From the list of available PCI devices, choose the one you want to pass to the guest. Confirm with Finish.

section.title: Summary
section.para: After having successfully assigned a &vmhost;'s PCI device to a &vmguest;, the &vmguest; can exclusively use its resources.

varlistentry.term: Does the PCI device refuse to get assigned?

listitem.para: Verify that the device is not assigned to another &vmguest; and that it is properly detached from the &vmhost;.
